titleStmt.title: A proclamation made by the States of the vnited Netherlands touching the defence of the safegard of the enemy, the breaking of the quarters with the enemies souldiours, which vndertake to come ouer the waters and bogs in the parts of Freesland, Ornlanden, Drente, and Westerwoldingerland, or Lordship of Wedde. Faithfully translated out of Dutch. Also a copie of a letter, to the honourable Lords, the States, bearing date the 21 of March, 1599. Touching the victorie atchieued by the Prince Maurites before Emmericke.
titleStmt.author: United Provinces of the Netherlands. Staten Generaal.

titleStmt.title: A proclamation made by the States of the vnited Netherlands touching the defence of the safegard of the enemy, the breaking of the quarters with the enemies souldiours, which vndertake to come ouer the waters and bogs in the parts of Freesland, Ornlanden, Drente, and Westerwoldingerland, or Lordship of Wedde. Faithfully translated out of Dutch. Also a copie of a letter, to the honourable Lords, the States, bearing date the 21 of March, 1599. publicationStmt.publisher: By [J. Windet for] Iohn Wolfe, and are to be sold at his shop in Popes head Alley, neere to the Exchange,

notesStmt.note: In two parts; the second part has a separate title page, with same imprint, reading: The copie of a letter written to the honorable Lords, the States, bearing date the 21 of March, 1599. Touching a victory atchieued by the Prince Maurits before Emmericke. Translated out of the copie, printed at Amsterdam.
Part 2 title page bound out of order, behind general title page.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A PROCLAMATION made by the States of the vnited Netherlands, touching the defence of the ≈øafegard of the enemy, the breaking of the quarters with the enemies ≈øouldiours, which vndertake to come ouer the waters and bogs in the parts of Free≈øland, Omlanden, Drente, and We≈øterwoldingerland, or Lord≈øhip of Wedde.
Al≈øo a Copie of a Letter, to the honourable Lords, the States, bearing date the 21 of March, 1599. Touching the victorie atchieued by the Prince Maurits before Emmericke.
Imprinted at London by Iohn Wolfe, and are to be ≈øold at his ≈øhop in Popes head Alley, neere to the Exchange. 1599.

div.head: The Copie of a Letter.
To the honorable Lords, the States, dated the 21 of March, 1599. touching victorie atchieued by the Prince Maurits before Emmericke.
div.p:
his princely excelencie writeth from Arnham the 19 of this pre≈øent month, to haue vi≈øited all the bordring citties, and haue fortified the ≈øame: To haue had intelligence, that the Cardinall being come towards Gelder, the Admirant vvas trauailed to meet him. That his princely excellency had found good to ≈øurpri≈øe the ca≈øtle of Zeuenter, vvith two hou≈øen. That the princes ≈øouldiors in Zeuenter not vvithout great difficulty, after three vollies of demy-cannons had yeelded vp the fort. That the Counte Lodowicke vvas mean vvhile ≈øent
vvith the hor≈øemen neere Emmerick, as ≈øuppo≈øing that the gari≈øons vvould come out to a≈øsi≈øt the afore≈øaid places, as indeed it happened: for they perceiuing ≈øome of our hor≈øemen hold a great pace, as if they had ≈øhunned the citty. The Earle of Bu≈øquoy, Gouernour of Emmericke (vvho≈øe vvife among≈øt others vvent to Spaine vvith the Archduke Albertus to fetch the Infanta) vvith a great troupe of the gari≈øon, came out of the citty to pur≈øue our hor≈ømen, vvhich they did a great vvay beyond the ambu≈øh, in≈øomuch, that being inclo≈øed, the ≈øaid Earle and two captains vvith many officers vvere taken, and very neer a hundreth drowned. Al≈øo thirty ≈øouldiours vvere ≈øet at liberty, for the vvhich the Earle hath promi≈øed ran≈øome, his per≈øon is vvounded, but (according to his excellencies vvriting) not mortally: declareth, that the enemy maketh daily great preparation to come into the field. God be prai≈øed for this good beginning.

div.head: ‚ùß A Proclamation made by the States of the vnited Nether-lands, touching the defence of the ≈øafegard of the enemie, the breaking of the quarters with the enemies ≈øouldiours, who vndertake to come ouer the waters and bogs in the parts of Free≈øeland, Omlanden, Drenthe, and We≈øterwoldingerland, or Lord≈øhip of Wedde.
div.p:
THe generall States of the vnited Nether-lands, to all tho≈øe vvhich ≈øhall ≈øee or heare the≈øe pre≈øent greeting. Whereas vvee are informed, that the enemie vvith a neuer-heard barbarous pre≈øumption, deceit and vvickedne≈ø≈øe (as if all vvhat he li≈øt to doe vvere lawfull) again≈øt all diuine, naturall, and humane lawes, again≈øt all faith, honor, oath, and beleefe, hauing mo≈øt lamentably and cruelly oppre≈ø≈øed, pilled, and infu≈øed the feeble, vnarmed, and guiltle≈ø≈øe, neutrall
cities and townes, yea of his be≈øt and vvell-vvillinge≈øt friends, and finally are ranged to the borders of the≈øe vnited Prouinces, vvhere although he vvas by the means of our might, and armes, through the wi≈øe and valiant conduct of his excellencie, next God, repul≈øed, and di≈øapointed of his enterpri≈øe, yet cea≈øeth not by letters, me≈ø≈øages, threats, and othervvaies, to procure diuers of our countries and inhabitants of the≈øe vnited Prouinces, as Free≈øeland, Omlanden, Drente, Oldampt, We≈øtervvoldingerland, or Lord≈øhip of Wedde, to come vnder his contribution, vnder colour of his ≈øafegard, as if hee (vvho in ≈øuch faithle≈ø≈øe, vvicked, and cruel ≈øort had behaued him≈øelfe towards the≈øe poore good neutrals, yea his owne friends) vvould behaue him≈øelfe faithfully and meekely towards our inhabitants his enemies. And being that vve are vvell a≈ø≈øured, that hee intendeth nothing els, then that hauing by the≈øe his adulations allured and enticed by little and little our good inhabitants to his deuotion, in the end vvith all crueltie and tirannie to handle them, and therefore thinke it mo≈øt expedient, by all po≈øsible meanes to preuent it. So it is, that
by deliberation of the coun≈øell of e≈øtate of the afore≈øaid vnited lands, vve haue interdicted and defended expre≈ø≈øely by the≈øe pre≈øents, on paine of our highe≈øt di≈øgrace and di≈øplea≈øure to be held as enemies, and vvithout anie fauour to be immediately puni≈øhed. All townes, villages, places, and quarters of Free≈øeland, Omlanden, Drente, Oldampt, and We≈øtervvoldingerland, together vvith the Officers, Magi≈øtrates, and inhabitants of the ≈øame, high and low, noble and ignoble, as vvell in generall as perticular, in any manner vvhat≈øoeuer not to take or receiue of the enemie anie ≈øafegard, or vnder pretext of the ≈øame to yeeld, accord, or pay the enemie any contribution, great or ≈ømall, or to harbour or hide anie of the enemies ≈øouldiours, or to receiue any me≈ø≈øage by mouth or letters of the enemie, and much le≈ø≈øe to hold any corre≈øpondence by mouth or vvritings vvith him. But to the contrarie, ordaine, vvill, and command expre≈ø≈øely all the afore≈øaid townes, villages, places, quarters, and inhabitants, vvithout delay to furni≈øh and prepare them≈øelues vpon the needful places to keep good watch, and by all needfull and due order, either by
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
≈øound of bels, hornes, or beacons, to a≈ø≈øemble them≈øelues; and iointly to vvith≈øtand, pur≈øue, and kill, or at lea≈øt, take pri≈øoners all ≈øuch foe-like ≈øouldiours, as ≈øhall pre≈øume, or dare to come ouer the vvaters and bogs into the≈øe territories. To vvhich end vvee likevvi≈øe declare, ordaine, and command, that henceforward no quarter ≈øhall be held with ≈øuch enemies or foe-like ≈øouldiours: Which keeping of quarter vve haue for that cau≈øe altogether and vvholly depo≈øed and renounced, as by the≈øe pre≈øents vve yet depo≈øe and renounce the ≈øame. Vpon paine, that vvho≈øoeuer henceforward ≈øhall bee found to haue kept quarter vvith the ≈øaid foe-like ≈øouldiors, or to haue in any ≈øort ≈øhewed them any fauour or kindne≈ø≈øe, that tho≈øe ≈øhall at the in≈øtant be ≈øtaied, and immediately vvithout any fauour puni≈øhed as the foe-like ≈øouldiors them≈øelues. And to the end, that euerie one may acquit him≈øelfe vvith more courage and zeale towards his enemie, vve haue agreed, and agree by the pre≈øents, for an honour and recompence to euerie one, bee hee ≈øouldiour or no ≈øouldiour, the ≈øumme of fi≈øt y100 ≈øhillings of Engli≈øh mony. guldens for euerie foe-like ≈øouldior, vvhich by
anie henceforward ≈øhal be killed (vpon good proofes) or at lea≈øtwi≈øe taken pri≈øoner. As al≈øo in like manner vve agree and promi≈øe the ≈øumme of fiue and twentieFifty ≈øhillings Engli≈øh mony. guldens, to each and euerie one vvho≈øoeuer, that ≈øhall ≈øurelie, trulie, and vvithout fraud accu≈øe anie one to the contrarie of our expre≈ø≈øe commaundements, vvhich ≈øhall haue receiued anie ≈øafegard, paied anie contribution, to haue harbored or hid anie of the afore≈øaid ≈øouldiours, to haue by mouth or by vvriting held anie corre≈øpondence vvith the enemie, or that hauing taken anie enemie, ≈øhall haue vvithout, or vpon ran≈øome, let him go. And to the end, that none may pretend ignorance of the≈øe our expre≈ø≈øe ordinances, We de≈øire our beloued States of Free≈ølaÃÑd, the city of Groningen, and Omlanden, or their deputies, and all others to vvhom it doth belong and appertaine, immediatly to cau≈øe proclamation and publication hereof to be made in euery and each citty, place, and quarter, vvhere it ≈øhall be needfull. As al≈øo earne≈øtly reque≈øting the noble Lord, the Earle William Lodowicke of Na≈ø≈øau, gouernour of Free≈øeland, the citty of Groningen & Omlanden, &c. vvill & command
expre≈ø≈øely all cheefetaines, knights, captaines, commanders, and common ≈øouldiours, hor≈øe and foot, by vvater and land, al≈øo all officers, iu≈øtices, and inhabitants, vnto vvhom this in any ≈øort may touch or belong, to gouerne them≈øelues according to the tenour hereof, and inuiolably to accompli≈øh and keep the contents of the ≈øame, vpon pain of the paines aboue named, for that vve haue found the ≈øame to bee mo≈øt expedient and nece≈ø≈øarie for the good of the Land.

closer.dateline: Giuen in S Grauen Haeghe, the twentith of March. 1599.

postscript.p: By the commandement of the Lords, the generall States of the vnited Netherlands.
And by the coun≈øell of e≈øtate of the ≈øame.

dateline.date: From the Haghe, the 21 of March, 1599.

div.p: Tho≈øe of Arnhem haue ≈øince reported, that aboue 150, which in the skirmi≈øh thinking to ≈øaue them≈øelues through the water, were drowned, and that among≈øt them were ≈øome with gold chaines. Tho≈øe of Emmericke repent them≈øelues alreadie to haue without any need taken the Spaniards in, which was again≈øt their promi≈øe.
